articles.headline: Slowing Economy Posing Test for Disney
articles.snippet: Since becoming chief executive of the Walt Disney Company two years ago, Robert A. Iger has dazzled Wall Street. Now, however, the company is sailing into some choppy waters
articles.abstract: Since becoming chief executive of the Walt Disney Company two years ago, Robert A. Iger has dazzled Wall Street. Now, however, the company is sailing into some choppy waters
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 12 — Since becoming chief executive of the Walt Disney Company two years ago, Robert A. Iger has dazzled Wall Street by delivering soaring profits and moving aggressively to fix trouble spots.

articles.headline: Speculation on E*Trade Hurts Stock
articles.snippet: The online brokerage is the latest financial company to struggle as a result of a large stake in complex bonds tied to the American housing market.
articles.abstract: The online brokerage is the latest financial company to struggle as a result of a large stake in complex bonds tied to the American housing market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shares of E*Trade Financial tumbled yesterday after an analyst suggested that the company might have to seek bankruptcy protection if panicked customers withdrew deposits because of the brokerage firm’s faltering mortgage investments.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Peter Edmonston

articles.headline: In Farm Belt, Ethanol Plants Hit Resistance
articles.snippet: The era in which a new ethanol distillery in agricultural America was greeted with delight seems to be ending.
articles.abstract: The era in which a new ethanol distillery in agricultural America was greeted with delight seems to be ending.
articles.lead_paragraph: SPARTA, Wis. — When plans were announced for a new ethanol distillery on the outskirts of this city of 9,000, residents complained that it would mar the view from the municipal golf course. They worried that its emissions would taint the milk-based products made at nearby Century Foods International, one of the community’s biggest employers. They even argued over whether the plant would reek like burned molasses or blackened popcorn or fermenting beer.

articles.headline: In Mixed Slice of Baghdad, Old Bonds Defy War
articles.snippet: In the neighborhood of Bab al Sheik, Sunnis, Shiites, Kurds and Christians live together with unusual ease.
articles.abstract: In the neighborhood of Bab al Sheik, Sunnis, Shiites, Kurds and Christians live together with unusual ease.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — At its oldest spot, a small dusty strip of dirt road near a mosque, the neighborhood of Bab al Sheik — a maze of snaking streets too narrow for cars — dates from a time, more than a thousand years ago, when Baghdad ruled the Islamic world.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise and Karim Hilmi

articles.headline: Software for Rent
articles.snippet: Salesforce.com wants to become a platform like Microsoft’s Windows operating system, a product so popular that it is the foundation for a veritable ecosystem of software developers.
articles.abstract: Salesforce.com wants to become a platform like Microsoft’s Windows operating system, a product so popular that it is the foundation for a veritable ecosystem of software developers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Marc Benioff has never been modest in his dreams for Salesforce.com, the business software company he founded in 1999.

articles.headline: Investment Firm Names Gore as a Partner
articles.snippet: The position at Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers will provide former Vice President Al Gore with an opportunity to nurture green businesses.
articles.abstract: The position at Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers will provide former Vice President Al Gore with an opportunity to nurture green businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12 — Deepening his ties to Silicon Valley, former Vice President Al Gore said on Monday that he had become a partner in the venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers.

articles.headline: Voter Anger May Free Up Energy Bills
articles.snippet: With the price of crude flirting with $100 a barrel, lawmakers may finally be preparing to pass a series of energy-saving measures.
articles.abstract: With the price of crude flirting with $100 a barrel, lawmakers may finally be preparing to pass a series of energy-saving measures.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 — Congress saw it coming. Earlier this year, lawmakers warned of an impending energy crisis as they debated wide-ranging legislation to improve automotive efficiency, reward energy conservation and spur development of alternative power sources.

articles.headline: 6 Palestinians Killed in Gaza at Fatah Rally
articles.snippet: Armed clashes between rival Palestinian factions broke out on the third anniversary of the death of Yasir Arafat.
articles.abstract: Armed clashes between rival Palestinian factions broke out on the third anniversary of the death of Yasir Arafat.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA, Nov. 12  At least six Palestinians were killed and more than 100 wounded here on Monday when a rally by the relatively pro-Western Fatah movement to mark the third anniversary of the death of its founder, Yasir Arafat, ended in armed clashes with its rival, Hamas.
articles.byline: By Taghreed El-Khodary and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: The Prince and His Palace: A 6,400-Square-Foot Getaway That Flies
articles.snippet: Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia will soon be able to claim bragging rights for the world’s largest private jet, which is priced at just over $300 million.
articles.abstract: Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia will soon be able to claim bragging rights for the world’s largest private jet, which is priced at just over $300 million.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS, Nov. 12 — He may be only the world’s 13th-richest man, but Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia will soon be able to claim the bragging rights to the world’s largest private jet.

articles.headline: A Health Plan for Wal-Mart: Less Stinginess
articles.snippet: The nation’s largest private employer is offering better coverage to a greater number of workers.
articles.abstract: The nation’s largest private employer is offering better coverage to a greater number of workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: For much of the last decade, the retailing behemoth Wal-Mart Stores has been associated with stingy health care as much as low prices.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Reed Abelson
